metadata.description: HydroRIVERS represents a vectorized line network of all global rivers that have a catchment area of at least 10 km² or an average river flow of at least 0.1 m³/sec, or both. HydroRIVERS has been extracted from the gridded HydroSHEDS core layers at 15 arc-second resolution. The global coverage of HydroRIVERS encompasses 8.5 million individual river reaches with an average length of 4.2 km, representing a total of 35.9 million km of rivers globally. HydroRIVERS only includes a limited amount of (mostly geometric) attribute information, such as the river reach length, the distance from upstream headwaters and ocean outlet, the river order, and an estimate of long-term average discharge. Every river reach is also co-registered to the sub-basin of the HydroBASINS database in which it resides (via a shared ID).

background: Water is a vital necessity to sustain life on Earth, and many Earth system processes depend on the spatial and temporal distribution of freshwater resources. The hydrological cycle and its underlying physical processes have been studied intensely over the past decades, mostly with a focus on small- to medium-sized catchments. In recent years, however, the increasing pressures on freshwater resources from a multitude of complex and interacting factors that span all scales led to a growing recognition of the importance of large river systems. As in situ measurements of many hydrologic variables at large spatial and temporal scales are difficult and expensive, global hydrological models (GHMs) have emerged as our preferred research tool to analyze current and future world water resources. Despite the increased attention, hydrological modeling at large scales has traditionally been hampered by a number of issues, including general limitations in our knowledge and understanding of the underlying processes for many regions of the Earth; incomplete, inconsistent, or highly uncertain data collections; a lack of spatial integration between models and datasets; and the difficulty to create models that support multi-scale or coupled approaches. To achieve this goal, new and enhanced global datasets and tools describing the geographical distribution of hydrological features, characteristics, and processes will be required as this information is currently often unavailable or at low quality.

Spatial information in GHMs is typically represented as layers of uniformly sized grid cells, also known as raster datasets. Vector datasets on the other hand consist of objects, represented as points at a certain location, or as a series of point locations chained together to form a line or polygon. Raster models have traditionally been the preferred choice of hydrological modelers since the integration of topography in the form of rasterized Digital Elevation Models (DEMs) is a key requirement for many routing algorithms that trace water along drainage direction maps. Furthermore, many ancillary datasets stem from remotely sensed raster information (e.g. land cover, precipitation, etc.), and grids are relatively easy to process in any modern GIS. Hydrological connectivity is an important concept in both hydrology and ecology. Flows in traditional GHMs that include lateral transport occur on the premise of a river continuum whereby conditions at every location in the river network are influenced by upstream processes (Vannote et al., 1980). The advanced implementation of hydrological connectivity in a modeling framework is an attractive concept because of its ability to integrate processes from multiple disciplines (such as terrestrial, climate, ecological and hydrological); because of its easiness to represent spatially explicit topology information of a river network and watershed landscape (up- and downstream relations); and because of its intrinsic ability to establish connections across multiple scales– from point locations and river reaches to nested catchments and entire basins.

The main limitations identified are related to spatial resolution, data structure, quality of data, inclusion of hydrological connectivity, and support of multi-scale and integrated modeling approaches.
research objective: In this paper, we argue that there is currently no comprehensive framework that can fully support integrated hydro-ecological modeling at the global scale; yet the building blocks of such a framework already exist. We will illustrate the current status and outline new directions for global scale hydro-ecological modeling to study the world’s large river systems. We propose an approach that combines existing and newly developed global scale hydrographic baseline data with a dedicated river routing model in a Geographic Information System (GIS) environment, and we will present preliminary results of our own model development. Finally, we will show that such a framework can enable a broad range of hydro-ecological applications and operate at scales at which local decision making and management becomes feasible.

We here propose to design a more integrated data and modeling framework which facilitates an easier linkage between hydrological and ecological information and is geared towards hydro-ecological research, applications, and management. In conclusion and to widen the scope of routing, tracing, and connectivity in hydrological models, for this paper, we define the term ‘river network routing’ following the hydrological connectivity concept of Pringle (2003) as ‘the simulation of movement of energy, material and species within a hydrological object space, based on flow routing, tracing and in-stream processing.’
In response, we proposed a versatile global hydrological modeling framework that addresses these limitations, providing support for a broad range of applications.
challenges: Despite significant recent advancements, global hydrological models and their input databases still show limited capabilities in supporting many spatially detailed research questions and integrated assessments, such as required in freshwater ecology or applied water resources management. The current spatial resolution of GHMs is not appropriate for many ecological or environmental management applications because of difficulties to accurately represent stream and watershed attributes and to precisely locate individual objects within the river system. The relatively coarse spatial resolution introduces bias and misrepresentation of hydrological processes and river topology. This can result, for example, in underestimation of river length and travel times and can lead to subsequent inaccuracies of travel-based attributes, e.g., sediment delivery to the ocean. The integration of local or fine-scale information is difficult, if not impossible.

A major limitation of the raster concept, however, is the difficulty to integrate objects or information from different sources or formats (such as the discharge time series of a gauging station; a reservoir outline; or a fish migration route) into one common framework, as linkages would have to be established to individual pixels. Yet, difficulties arise from inherent data and modeling characteristics. For example, certain types of geospatial hydrological data, such as runoff coefficients or flow directions, cannot be easily scaled by spatial resampling techniques. We are currently not aware of models that can fully implement such advanced up- and downstream routing in a global framework. Thus, for the primary goal of a first-level integration of baseline hydrology with ecological and other applications at the global scale, we believe that the full implementation of hydrodynamic processes, though desirable, is currently not a stringent priority.

The main limitations identified are related to spatial resolution, data structure, quality of data, inclusion of hydrological connectivity, and support of multi-scale and integrated modeling approaches.
methods: We described the enhancement of a global hydrographic database (HydroSHEDS) and the coupled development of a new river network routing model (HydroROUT) as the backbone of our framework.
dataset: HydroSHEDS is a hydrographic mapping product created by World Wildlife Fund that provides river and watershed information for regional and global-scale applications in a consistent format (Lehner et al., 2008). It offers a suite of geo-referenced datasets at various resolutions ranging from 3 arc-second (approximately 90 m at the equator) to 30 arc-second, including river networks, watershed boundaries, and drainage directions. In nearly all GHMs, the implemented routing models operate on raster data. Only recently, some large-scale models started to shift towards a vector environment (e.g. Paiva et al., 2011) or use advanced sub-grid and/or hybrid structures (e.g. Yamazaki et al., 2011).
findings: Our case studies showed the potential of the model and data development to facilitate and conduct hydro-ecological research at the global scale.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used for understanding river network topology in global hydrological models?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method is the use of HydroSHEDS, which is a hydrographic mapping product that provides river and watershed information for regional and global-scale applications. It includes geo-referenced datasets at various resolutions, such as river networks and drainage directions, allowing for analysis of river network topology.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a dataset that supports multi-scale hydrological modeling approaches?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset supporting multi-scale hydrological modeling is HydroRIVERS, which provides a vectorized line network of global rivers with attributes like river length and average flow estimates. This dataset supports analyses of river network topology and hydrological connectivity at various scales.

Definition.Question: How does spatial resolution impact the effectiveness of global hydrological models?
Definition.Answer: The spatial resolution of global hydrological models significantly impacts their effectiveness, as the current resolutions are often not suitable for ecological or environmental management applications. Coarse spatial resolution can lead to inaccuracies in representing stream and watershed attributes, misrepresentation of river topology, and misestimation of river length and travel times. This can subsequently cause inaccuracies in travel-based attributes, such as sediment delivery to the ocean.

Definition.Question: What role does the HydroSHEDS dataset play in global hydrological modeling?
Definition.Answer: The HydroSHEDS dataset provides hydrographic mapping products that offer river and watershed information for regional and global-scale applications in a consistent format. It includes geo-referenced datasets like river networks, watershed boundaries, and drainage directions at various resolutions, which are crucial for developing routing models and enhancing global hydrological databases. HydroSHEDS serves as the foundation for the development of models that facilitate hydro-ecological research and applications.

Comparison.Question: What are the main challenges faced in integrating hydrological and ecological datasets on a global scale compared to regional scales?
Comparison.Answer: On a global scale, the integration of hydrological and ecological datasets is challenged by limitations in spatial resolution, data structure, and the quality of data, which impede the accurate representation of stream and watershed attributes. Regional scales can often manage finer details and local information more effectively. Global scales require new frameworks to support multi-scale approaches and better integration of hydrological connectivity.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges do current global hydrological models face in accurately representing stream and watershed attributes, and how might new datasets address these issues?
Interpretation.Answer: Current global hydrological models face challenges such as coarse spatial resolution, leading to biases in river length, travel times, and hydrological processes. These inaccuracies can affect attributes like sediment delivery and ecological dynamics. New datasets, possibly with higher resolution and improved data structures, could provide more precise stream and watershed representations, thus enhancing model accuracy for ecological and water resource management applications.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons for the challenges faced in integrating multi-scale and coupled approaches in global hydrological modeling?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in integrating multi-scale and coupled approaches in global hydrological modeling arise from several factors, including spatial resolution limitations, the quality and consistency of data, and the difficulty in representing accurate hydrological connectivity. The coarse spatial resolution can lead to misrepresentation of stream and watershed attributes, which affects the accuracy of hydrological models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the limited capabilities of global hydrological models in supporting spatially detailed research questions, particularly in freshwater ecology?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The limited capabilities of global hydrological models in supporting spatially detailed research questions are primarily caused by the coarse spatial resolution of existing datasets, which introduces bias and misrepresentation of hydrological processes and river topology. This can lead to inaccuracies in attributes such as river length and travel times, which are crucial for ecological and environmental management applications.

Causal Consequence.Question: How do challenges related to spatial resolution and data structure impact the effectiveness of global hydrological models in supporting ecological applications?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Challenges related to spatial resolution and data structure can significantly impact the effectiveness of global hydrological models by limiting their ability to accurately represent stream and watershed attributes. This can lead to misrepresentation of hydrological processes, such as river length and travel times, ultimately affecting the precision of ecological applications. The coarse spatial resolution often introduces biases, hindering the integration of fine-scale ecological information into global models.

Causal Consequence.Question: What potential advancements or outcomes could result from the enhancement of a global hydrographic database and the development of a new river network routing model?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The enhancement of a global hydrographic database and the development of a new river network routing model could lead to significant advancements in hydro-ecological research. These improvements can provide a more integrated framework that supports multi-scale modeling and facilitates the linkage between hydrological and ecological information. This can enable a broader range of applications, enhance the analysis of large river systems, and improve the precision of environmental management and decision-making processes at various scales.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it significant to develop a comprehensive framework that supports integrated hydro-ecological modeling on a global scale?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Developing a comprehensive framework for integrated hydro-ecological modeling on a global scale is significant because it addresses the limitations of current models, such as inadequate spatial resolution and data integration. Such a framework would allow for better linkage between hydrological and ecological information, supporting a diverse range of applications and management decisions. It would also facilitate the simulation of the movement of energy, material, and species within hydrological systems, enhancing the understanding and management of freshwater resources.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives drive the enhancement of global hydrographic databases and the development of new river network routing models in this field?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives driving the enhancement of global hydrographic databases and the development of new river network routing models are to create more robust and versatile datasets that support accurate representation and analysis of river networks and watershed attributes. This includes improving spatial resolution, data structure, and quality, as well as incorporating hydrological connectivity to enable comprehensive hydro-ecological research and applications. These developments aim to overcome existing challenges in modeling and provide reliable data for global-scale studies and decision-making processes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What is the procedure for creating a global hydrological model that integrates both raster and vector datasets effectively?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure involves enhancing a global hydrographic database such as HydroSHEDS and developing a coupled river network routing model, like HydroROUT, to serve as the framework's backbone. This approach allows for the integration of raster data, which is typically used for routing models, with vector data to improve spatial representation and connectivity in hydrological modeling.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can challenges related to spatial resolution and data structure be addressed when developing a dataset for large river systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges related to spatial resolution and data structure can be addressed by employing global hydrological models that support multi-scale and integrated modeling approaches. Efforts should be made to enhance the spatial resolution of datasets, such as HydroSHEDS, to reduce bias and improve the accuracy of hydrological processes and river topology representation, ensuring precise location of stream and watershed attributes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are recommended for improving the quality and integration of hydrological datasets for large-scale ecological applications?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Improving the quality and integration of hydrological datasets can be achieved by using advanced global datasets and tools like HydroSHEDS, which provide geo-referenced datasets at various resolutions. The integration of raster and vector datasets can be facilitated by using models that operate in a Geographic Information System (GIS) environment, allowing for spatially explicit representation and analysis of hydrological connectivity and processes across multiple scales.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of vector and raster data environments enable more comprehensive hydrological modeling at large scales?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of vector and raster data environments allows for the detailed representation of river networks and watershed landscapes, enhancing hydrological connectivity and enabling multi-scale and integrated modeling approaches.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or methods enable the accurate estimation of river attributes such as length, flow direction, and connectivity in global hydrological models?
Enablement.Answer: Accurate estimation of river attributes is enabled by using high-resolution datasets, like those derived from HydroSHEDS, which provide detailed geographical distribution information and support advanced methods for hydrological connectivity and routing.

Expectation.Question: Why might the integration of local or fine-scale information into global hydrological models be challenging, and how can this challenge be addressed?
Expectation.Answer: The integration of local or fine-scale information is challenging due to the coarse spatial resolution of global hydrological models, which can introduce bias and misrepresentation of hydrological processes and river topology. This difficulty arises from the inability to accurately represent stream and watershed attributes or precisely locate individual objects within the river system. Addressing this challenge requires the development of models that can incorporate advanced routing and connectivity concepts, which can facilitate a more accurate representation of spatially detailed research questions and integrated assessments.

Expectation.Question: Why do hydrological datasets often have limitations regarding spatial resolution and data structure, and what improvements could be made to enhance their usability for ecological applications?
Expectation.Answer: Hydrological datasets often face limitations in spatial resolution and data structure because traditional models use raster data which can be difficult to integrate with diverse data types and formats, such as discharge time series or reservoir outlines. These limitations impact the ability to conduct spatially detailed research and integrate hydrological connectivity. Improvements could include developing more integrated data and modeling frameworks that support multi-scale approaches and facilitate easier linkage between hydrological and ecological information.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected outcomes of enhancing global hydrographic databases with new river network routing models, and how might these enhancements support hydro-ecological research?
Expectation.Answer: Enhancing global hydrographic databases with new river network routing models is expected to provide a framework that supports hydro-ecological research and management applications at a global scale. These enhancements can enable a broad range of applications by offering more detailed and accurate representation of river networks, which can improve the integration of ecological and hydrological information, facilitate the study of large river systems, and support local decision-making and management.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the potential for enhancing global hydro-ecological modeling with existing and new global hydrographic baseline data?
Judgmental.Answer: The potential is significant, as combining existing and newly developed global hydrographic baseline data with dedicated river routing models in GIS environments can enable a broad range of hydro-ecological applications. This approach supports multi-scale integration and can facilitate local decision-making and management.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the prospects for improving the quality and applicability of datasets used in global hydrological models through advancements in data collection techniques?
Judgmental.Answer: Prospects for improvement are promising with the development of enhanced datasets and tools, such as HydroSHEDS and HydroROUT, which provide higher resolution and more consistent data for hydrological and ecological research. These advancements can address current limitations in spatial resolution, data quality, and integration, thereby broadening the scope and application of global hydrological models.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods can accurately represent stream and watershed attributes at a global scale.
Assertion.Answer: The main limitations in global hydrological models and their input databases are related to spatial resolution, data structure, and quality of data, which can introduce biases and misrepresentations in stream and watershed attributes. These challenges make it difficult to precisely represent attributes and locate individual objects within the river system.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the effectiveness of integrating hydrological connectivity in data collection for large-scale river systems.
Assertion.Answer: Hydrological connectivity is crucial in both hydrology and ecology as it integrates processes from multiple disciplines. However, implementing advanced connectivity in a global framework is challenging due to limitations in spatial resolution, data structure, and current models' capabilities to fully integrate these processes.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how a dataset can support multi-scale and integrated modeling approaches for hydro-ecological research.
Assertion.Answer: The integration of local or fine-scale information into global datasets presents challenges, such as the difficulty in accurately representing hydrodynamic processes, spatial resolution issues, and the need for enhanced data and modeling frameworks that facilitate the linkage between hydrological and ecological information.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the main challenges in collecting and integrating hydrological data for large-scale river systems in the Himalayan region.
Request/Directive.Answer: The main challenges include spatial resolution, data structure, quality of data, inclusion of hydrological connectivity, and support of multi-scale and integrated modeling approaches. These challenges arise due to difficulties in accurately representing stream and watershed attributes, the coarse spatial resolution of global hydrological models (GHMs), and the inability to accurately integrate fine-scale information.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the methods used in the enhancement of global hydrographic databases and the development of river network routing models.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methods described involve the enhancement of a global hydrographic database (HydroSHEDS) and the coupled development of a new river network routing model (HydroROUT) as the backbone of the framework. This approach facilitates the integration of hydrological and ecological information and supports hydro-ecological research and applications.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that could be utilized for improving hydrological modeling in large river systems and explain their relevance.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets include HydroSHEDS, which provides river and watershed information for regional and global-scale applications. It offers geo-referenced datasets at various resolutions, including river networks, watershed boundaries, and drainage directions. These datasets are crucial for facilitating hydro-ecological research and improving hydrological modeling by providing consistent and detailed geographical information.
